body:
But the way that default_asset_host_protocol was written in @chriseppstein's original commit (https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/0e5891ad918ea975f8687d6d47aed5543afc7441), it is designed to behave sensibly when it's left at its initial nil value.

Safari's RSS reader fails to resolve the relative urls properly - an image url of //example.com/foo.jpg in a feed at http://example.com/foo.rss will results in a final url of http://example.com//example.com/foo.jpg.  In an ideal world I agree that the client ought to be fixing it, but that doesn't sound practical.  IE's double-download behaviour with protocol-relative stylesheets is a good example: it would be great if Microsoft would fix it, but in the meantime Rails specifies absolute urls on css.
